Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it pleases - "waiting my turn" -, and the "Nootjes" patrol seems to hold a rather different sense of entitlement, apparently expecting the US to comply with their whims. Fortunately, the US manages to hold privileged first-world opinions over these. Bullet 200.

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to Universal’s scope and scale. But the editing here is strange: attempting to tell the life of Douglas Munro in just over an hour to fill a feature film length narrative. Repeated training missions are laughable and fanatical military drill instructors appear and disappear without really moving the plot. Like other

Snow White is in my opinion a bad movie on an artistic point of view. The plot is pretty much foreseeable, the characters are stereotypes, the editing too. The movie is pale by comparison to Begin Again, where music flows through like a river. The biggest mistake to me is that the picture was pretty much devoid of magic. The park scenes, the pranks are enough to make a film that could blow any found footage movie out of the water.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is going to be criticized by some because it has very little action in it but I recommend it for what it is which is basically a TV series that was transferred to the big screen with a larger budget but also a much smaller box office return.
